lines.text: That's a good story.
Yeah, but whoever heard of dogs playing poker?
Now they're after my father! What did I ever do to them?
He shot at Mame!

[as Long Tom]
He never shot at Mame before.
This time he's gone too far.
Do you think your grandfather will remember?
He usually doesn't even remember what he had for breakfast.

[during the middle of a shootout, turns and sees a woman on the incoming train]
Ma?
[panics]
It's my Ma!
Ah, the carnival. The great American celebration of freedom, fun, and food.
I know you don't like being on a leash, but there's too much going on today for you to be running around here by yourself.
But that's what carnivals are all about, Joe, running around, free! Maybe getting fed for free!
What exactly are corn dogs made of?
No cotton candy, Wishbone.
No cotton can - Oh, no this is going too far.
I have rights. Freedom of speech, freedom of treats, freedom to go outside when I need to.

[to Marcus]
Are you enjoying the carnival?
How come nobody's asking the tied-up little dog if he's enjoying the -
[drops part of the leash from his mouth]
Eating is such a civilized activity.
Next they'll be saying *my* papers are forged.
You'd be surprised what a few people can do. Especially when they know the truth.
It's never too late for your best friend.

[repeated line; as Long Bill]
I don't have a gun!

[reading the comics]
So then the dog says, "I don't *have* a gun." Hahahahaha! Oh... that's funny.
Come on up here, little fella.
Boys, I'll handle this.
Now you see what I mean when I say no one ever listens to the dog?
I can't believe you found it, Wishbone.
What's so hard to believe? I'm a dog of many talents, *when* I'm not on a *leash*.
Wishbone, would you care to join me for breakfast?
Oh, yes. Always room for another breakfast.

The Old West has always held a special place in our imagination. Out of these tugged territories came folk heroes, who lived out our dreams of the unspoiled frontier, where freedom was cherished, and a simple code of honor bound people together. O. Henry captured the Old West for all time in his short stories. They may be short, but the colorful characters and surprise endings stick to our ribs for a long time.
[last lines]
WII-HOOO! Ha ha ha haa! ANyway, I'll give you the story...
